executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Ocean and coastal transportation companies, including freight transporters and cruise lines, have had a very turbulent five years. A rebound in the economy has been spelling excellent news for the cruise sector as more consumers are back on the sea for vacations, generating more revenue. But, price shocks and geopolitical issues have raised the expense of doing business for the ocean freight market, impacting their freights and revenue. So, industry revenue decreased at a CAGR of 0.5% to $46.5 billion by the end of 2024, despite a boost of 2.7% in 2024 alone. The rollout of new types of ships, like ultra-large commercial vessels, has been helping add more boats to the mix. But costs remain a factor that many cannot avoid because of the high expenses associated with operating maritime vehicles. The addition of inflationary pressures has also been raising the bar, as ocean freights and cruises have been raising their prices to varying degrees of success. Freight transporters have been using the Jones Act monopoly to fare far better. Still, despite these efforts, profit has been going downhill because of how uncontrollable these factors have been recently. Rising consumer spending will help cruise lines earn more revenue through the next period. The trend of environmental sustainability will help uplift and modernize fleets of ships in the industry, helping add more competition while complying with regulatory barriers in the future. Geopolitical issues also will remain a factor that will cut into the industry's performance.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Cruise Lines is a Major Save for the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The cruise lines segment has been a saving grace for this industry. Being a popular form of travel, this segment has been gaining attraction as consumer spending and total recreation expenditures have been picking up speed recently.

Inflation has recently become a significant reason for rising costs. Higher prices of goods impact many sectors, including this industry, which has to Absorb these costs to keep its operations afloat.

As Ultra Large Commercial Vessels (ULCVs) roll out, they have been shaking up the market. This new development has ensured tighter internal price competition as carriers have had to reduce shipping rates to strengthen capacity utilization.

The initial shock of the Russia-Ukraine war and the war between Israel and Hamas has rippling impacts on the global economy, shuttering certain regions or endangering routes like the Red Sea that has since become a hotbed for attacks by Houthis.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Improving Spending as US Consumers Make Discretionary Purchases
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: US consumers will spend more over the next five years. More spending will help promote manufacturing activity, bringing heightened revenue for this industry as it handles the flow of goods from downstream sectors that are rebounding more in the period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Various Geopolitical Issues Will Put More in Harm's Way
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Geopolitical issues will remain a very contentious factor in the industry, as they have been affecting various logistical services and routes because of their volatility, as they can either calm down or heat up.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Price Competition Will Expand In Line With Industry Expansion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy recovers, establishments and enterprises will rally similarly. This trend also signals increased consolidation activity among transportation carriers. With more new entrants, price-based competition will stay the norm for the foreseeable future.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: More Companies Will Implement Sustainable Shipping Practices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Environmental concerns and regulations are driving a shift toward more sustainable practices in the industry over the next five years. Companies that want to lower their contributions to global warming and climate change.

industry_definition: This industry provides deep-sea, coastal and Great Lakes water transportation, including using the St. Lawrence Seaway. It encompasses US-flagged and non-US-flagged vessels, though operators must primarily be US-based. Marine transportation services active on the St. Lawrence River are part of the Great Lakes Water Transportation System and, therefore, are included in this report. The industry also provides deep-sea passenger services like cruise ships.
key_trends: Big names bank on brand recognition
Air freight is rapidly faster but pricier than ocean transportation
The industry is battling inflation by raising prices
Security remains a top concern amid geopolitical instability
AP Moller–Maersk Group leads the industry with its vast global reach and robust logistics operations
Fuel Expenses Are High and Unstable
The Southeast's warm climate makes it a prime maritime hub
The Mid-Atlantic region's infrastructure boosts its maritime significance
International shipping companies face fierce competition
Cruise and resort-style passenger ships account for most of the industry's revenue

market_segmentation.segment_description: Customers buying tickets directly for personal use.
Businesses shipping goods with freight transport services.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes cruise ships and resort-style passenger ships that offer round-trip vacations to international destinations lasting from three days to more than three months.
The major aspect of this segment includes freight activity from US-based companies that trek across the international region to deliver goods sold as imports or exports.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Coastal and Great Lakes Freight Transportation
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes short-sea shipping, waterborne cargo and passenger movement between relatively close locations connected by waterways or oceans.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Coastal and Great Lakes Passenger Transportation
products_and_services.product_description: One of the major selling points for this segment is how it offers trips along the Great Lakes area, with many bodies of water that many passengers on cruises, ferry boats or ocean liners can see while on their voyages.

tier_1_suppliers: Dry Docks & Cargo Inspection Services in the US
Transportation and Warehousing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Heavy Engineering Construction in the US
tier_1_buyers: Tugboat & Shipping Navigational Services in the US
Local Freight Trucking in the US
Long-Distance Freight Trucking in the US
Port & Harbor Operations in the US
tier_2_buyers: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US
General Warehousing & Storage in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Growing United States trade activity boosts revenue for the industry, which handles US imports and exports abroad.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast boasts an extensive coastline with significant ports like Miami, Charleston and Jacksonville.
The Port of Long Beach, California and Los Angeles have enough market activity to drive this sector.
The Mid-Atlantic region is a key hub for waterborne freight because of its strategic position for transatlantic transport.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Navigable waters, including primary channels and harbors, are under the jurisdiction of the US Coast Guard and the Army Corps of Engineers.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE PASSENGER VESSEL SERVICES ACT OF 1886
regulations_points.regulation_description: This legislation bars foreign ships from transporting passengers directly between US ports.
This regulation aims to ensure dependable domestic shipping completely under US control.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New entrants face strict regulations at state, federal and international levels.
Formidable start-up costs raise barriers to entry.
Major cruise lines enjoy strong brand recognition.

basis_points.basis_description: Big names bank on brand recognition.
Air freight is rapidly faster but pricier than ocean transportation.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The largest businesses are in the freight transportation sector.
Competitive barriers prevent smaller companies from entering the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wage Cost is Scaling Down Amid Changes in the Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor costs comprise a significant expense for this industry, as it relies on a crew of workers to operate the ship and maintain its stability during voyages.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Fuel is the Top Expense But is Very Volatile
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Ship, fuel and equipment purchases represent one of this industry's most significant cost structure components.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Costs Cuts Through The Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Additional costs may build up for companies in this industry, mainly because of repairs and maintenance, along with IT work and obligatory taxes on cruises and ocean liners.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry's capital intensity is high because of the regular depreciation of equipment, ships and other assets.

volatility_points.volatility_title: ECONOMIC CONDITIONS IMPACT CONSUMER SPENDING BEHAVIOR
volatility_points.volatility_description: Economic downturns reduce consumers' disposable income, impacting their ability to spend on discretionary items like cruises.

volatility_points.volatility_title: VOLATILE FUEL PRICES AND LONG SHIPBUILDING TIMES DRIVE INDUSTRY INSTABILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The lengthy ship ordering and building process often leads to mismatched supply and demand forecasts.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: AUTONOMOUS VESSEL TECHNOLOGY CHANGING THE GAME
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies can significantly cut labor expenses by drastically reducing the need for crew onboard.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: SMART PORTS ENHANCING CARGO HANDLING AND EFFICIENCY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Innovations like port automation accelerate the cargo handling process for the industry.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by changing import volumes from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Rising imports will often generate revenue for US freight operations, who will see higher demand for services.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of consumer spending?
FAQs.answer: Consumer spending is responsible for a majority of revenue throughout the industry.

FAQs.question: Is your company located in proximity to important suppliers?
FAQs.answer: US producers are often looking to use freight operators within close proximity to carry their exports.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising oil prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: High oil prices can lead to increased demand for ocean and coastal transportation services for crude oil transportation.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Employment has been declining in the industry as a result of heavy automation on freight shipping in particular.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: New technology for route management and operations monitoring has been increasing.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: In general, tariffs are bad for revenue as prices will increase and international trade is increasingly discouraged.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Ocean pollution and emissions standards are increasingly becoming a public concern.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Economies of scale and efficient management of capacity are crucial methods for maintaining strong profit margins.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to major competitors?
FAQs.answer: Ability to turn inventory over quickly and load/unload efficiently is a crucial factor in determining an operator's competitiveness.

FAQs.question: How successful has your company been in matching the supply of its services to demand in the market?
FAQs.answer: Knowledge and experience of market variables and trends is crucial for forecasting demand and scheduling routes.

FAQs.question: What advantages do you offer to customers?
FAQs.answer: In a quickly expanding industry with diversified cruise experiences, it's important to stay on top of consumer experience.
